user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskMatch_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskMatch_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_task_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token);

    if (pthread_equal(pthread_self(), impl->id) == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TaskMatch_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_task_internal_record_t OS_impl_task_table[OS_MAX_TASKS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_t id;
} OS_impl_task_internal_record_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. In the call OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_task_table, *token) the macro parameter tok expands to *token so &(tok) becomes &(*token) which is equivalent to token — this takes the address of the object referred to by the pointer but does not modify the function parameter itself. The pointer parameter is not assigned to or otherwise altered, so MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is not violated.
